thread.title: Golf wrap: Morgan Hoffmann in hunt for victory
thread.title_full: Golf wrap: Morgan Hoffmann in hunt for victory

title: Golf wrap: Morgan Hoffmann in hunt for victory
text:
Golf wrap: Morgan Hoffmann in hunt for victory October 25, 2015 Last updated: Sunday, October 25, 2015, 1:21 AM THE ASSOCIATED PRESS | Print 
LAS VEGAS — In his fifth career PGA Tour start, Brett Stegmaier led the field — and Morgan Hoffmann was right behind him. 
Stegmaier birdied the final hole Saturday for a 3-under 68 and a one-stroke lead in the Shriners Hospitals for Children Open. 
Hoffmann was second after a 69 in the third round. After making four birdies in a four-hole stretch, the Wyckoff native hooked his drive on 18 into the desert rocks and ended up saving bogey with a 10-foot putt. 
"I was just saying if I could see the ball in there and it wasn’t in the bush, I’d give it a shot," said Hoffmann, 26. "Yeah, lucky to get out of there with bogey." 
Stegmaier rebounded for a bogey on the par-3 17th with a 13-foot birdie putt on the par-4 18th to reach 13-under 68. The former University of Florida player, 32, completed a second-round 66. 
"It played a little tougher, so played a little more conservatively," Stegmaier said. "Certainly happy to make four birdies and one bogey and be in the lead." 
Jimmy Walker, former UNLV player Chad Campbell and 2011 winner Kevin Na were tied for third at 11-under. Walker had a 69, Na shot 68 and Campbell 70. 
"I think that the pins are a lot more difficult than they normally are; a lot of tough pins," Walker said. "It’s like they don’t want us to make birdies. A lot of holes, par is pretty good here." 
Alex Cejka had a hole-in-one on the 212-yard 17th in a 66 that left him at 10-under. Rickie Fowler was tied for 28th at 6-under after a 70. 
Ko leads by four shots 
TAIPEI, Taiwan — Lydia Ko took a four-stroke lead in the LPGA Taiwan Championship, putting the 18-year-old New Zealander in position to regain the top spot in the world ranking. 
Ko had four birdies in a five-hole stretch and closed with another birdie for a 5-under 67 in windy conditions at rain-soaked Miramar. 
South Korea’s Eun-Hee Ji, a stroke ahead after each of the first two rounds, was second after a 72. England’s Charley Hull was another shot back after a 71.
